Award.AwardTitle: Conference Support for the 2019 Ribosome Meeting; January 6-10, 2019, Merida, Mexico

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support early career researcher attendance at the Ribosome Structure and Function Meeting, which will be held at the Fiesta Americana Hotel in Merida Mexico on January 6-10, 2019. An important aim of the conference is to provide early career researchers with experiences that help them develop professional skills. The format of the conference is a combination of talks, poster sessions and informal meetings. This format promotes scientific exchange in both formal and informal settings, and provides opportunities for networking with leaders in the field of ribosome research.

Protein synthesis is catalyzed by the ribosome, the ancient and evolutionary conserved cellular machine. Although recent decades have brought a basic understanding of the mechanisms of protein synthesis, many aspects of translation remain largely unanswered. These aspects include the ribosome dynamics during translocation, tRNA selection and peptide release, the kinetics of individual steps of translation, the modes of action of many protein synthesis inhibitors and many others. An overarching goal of the meeting is to bring together researchers working on different aspects of translation, exploiting different experimental approaches and using different experimental models. The most recent discoveries related to the ribosome will be presented within 10 scientific sessions structured around thematic topics. The scientific program will showcase advanced techniques and the use of multidisciplinary approaches for solving key biological problems related to gene expression and protein synthesis. In addition to the oral and poster presentations the organizers plan to disseminate the information through a special volume of one of the mainstream scientific journals, with chapters written by invited speakers and trainees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Conference ?Ribosome 2019: Structure and Function? took place January 6-10 in M?rida (Mexico). The purpose of the meeting was to promote scientific exchange among researchers working in the burgeoning field of protein synthesis.

 

The  main outcome of the project was the success of the meeting. It brought together nearly than 260 researchers from more than 20 countries. Participants of the meeting were able to present their recent findings in a series of talks and at two poster sessions informing participants about the recent progress in studying the molecular mechanisms of translation, translation regulation, pathologies associated with the ribosome malfunction and antibiotics that target the ribosome.

One of the important outcomes was that graduate students, postdocs and other scientists at the early stages of their career were able to directly interact with the leading researchers including two Nobel Prize winners, Drs. Ada Yonath and Joachim Frank, who participated in the meeting.

The informal atmosphere of the meeting was conducive to an easy scientific exchange. Furthermore, three common dinners and the fact that most of the participant stayed in the hotel which provided the main venue for the meeting additionally stimulated exchange of ideas and creating new collaborations.

Participants of the meeting were able to get familiar with the life of ordinary Mexican people in a traditional, authentic and not-touristic town on the Yucatan peninsula. This was especially important for the younger scientists working in the general field of life sciences in order to understand the importance of conducting basic and applied research for the good of people irrespective of their origin or financial status.
